Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: SciDaaS - Data Management as a Service

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The SciDaaS project will develop and operate a suite of innovative research data management services for the NSF community. These services, to be accessible at www.globusonline.org, will allow research laboratories to outsource a range of time-consuming research data management functions, including storage and movement, publication, and metadata management. SciDaaS research will investigate what services are most needed by NSF researchers; how best to present these services to integrate with diverse research laboratory environments; and how these services are used in practice across different research communities.

SciDaaS will greatly reduce the cost to the individual researcher of acquiring and operating sophisticated scientific data management capabilities. In so doing, it has the potential to dramatically expand use of advanced information technology in NSF research and thus accelerate discovery across many fields of science and engineering. By providing a platform for researchers to publicly share data at an incremental cost, SciDaaS will also reduce barriers to free exchange among researchers and contribute to the democratization of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a new approach to meeting the research data management needs of small and medium laboratories, based on software as a service (SaaS) approaches. Rather than providing researchers with sophisticated software that they must install, operate, and maintain, we showed how to delivere Scientific Data management as a Service (SciDaaS), comprising advanced capabilities for managing large scale datasets using simple and intuitive Web interfaces.

The primary goal of the project was to deliver services that take a much wider range of research data management tasks off researchers’ hands, building on the established Globus platform that has provided high performance, secure file transfer capabilities to researchers since November 2010. To this end, the project has supported the development of important new Globus capabilities, notably Globus publication, which extends file sharing with workflow tools for capturing metadata associated with a dataset, assigning a persistent identifier (e.g., DOI), curating collections of dataset, and discovering datasets by searching their metadata.

Over the past year, our operations team achieved 99.9% availability (131.6 minutes of unplanned and planned downtime) of the service (including planned and unplanned downtime) and followed a frequent release schedule. Our user support team resolved 1,733 tickets with 8,104 updates to tickets. Overall usage of Globus services continues to increase, up to 100,000 registered users as of 2018.
